Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2015
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2015, Research Using Biological Collections. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow to take transformative approaches to grand challenges in biology that employ biological collections in highly innovative ways. The title of the research plan for this fellowship to Dr. Kristina Cammen is "Evolutionary ecology of population decline and rebound in pinniped species in the Northwest Atlantic." The host institutions for this fellowship are the University of Maine, Orono and St. Mary's University, and the sponsoring scientists are Dr. Michael Kinnison and Dr. Timothy Frasier.

Many species today have been broadly shaped by a shared history of population decline followed, in some cases, by subsequent recovery. Evolutionary theories predict that these periods of bottleneck and exponential growth will result in the reduction and expansion of genetic diversity, respectively; however, these hypotheses have rarely been tested in natural populations. Past limitations to empirical assessment have been largely due to the difficulties of sampling across appropriate temporal and spatial scales, but these limitations can be addressed with the use of long-term biological collections and archaeological samples. Through access to such sample collections from the NOAA Northeast Fisheries Science Center, the University of Maine, Dalhousie University, and St. Mary's University, the fellowship research study documents the genomic signature of population decline, growth, and expansion in gray and harbor seals in the Northwest Atlantic. Historically, harbor and gray seals were largely extirpated from US waters in this region, but within the past several decades both species have rapidly rebounded and expanded. Recently developed genomic approaches, e.g., RAD sequencing, are being used to investigate change in both neutral and adaptive genetic markers, representing complementary evolutionary forces of drift and selection, which may respond in different directions and at different time lags to demographic shifts. In addition, analyses of adaptive markers may facilitate the identification of new candidate genes related to dispersal across populations and evolutionary rescue within populations. This research is particularly relevant within the context of rising ocean temperature that may further alter population abundance and range in the future.

Training goals for the fellowship have a particular focus on further developing analytical, bioinformatics, and laboratory skills to advance the development of the Fellow's career and research agenda in ecological and evolutionary genomics. In addition, educational outreach is dedicated to broadening the participation of women in STEM and building scientific and leadership skills in K-12 and undergraduate students by providing hands-on research experiences and developing and distributing case study teaching materials that incorporate the proposed research process and outcomes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the support of an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology (Grant No. 1523568), Dr. Kristina Cammen completed a research project entitled “Evolutionary ecology of population decline and rebound in sympatric pinniped species in the Northwest Atlantic,” under the mentorship of sponsoring scientists Dr. Michael Kinnison at the University of Maine and Dr. Timothy Frasier at St. Mary’s University (Halifax, Nova Scotia). Using complementary mitochondrial and genomic approaches, Dr. Cammen’s research revealed changes in the diversity of gray and harbor seals in the Northwest Atlantic over the past 500 years.  Through the study of long-term biological collections, including archaeological and contemporary samples, this research described genomic signatures of population bottleneck, recovery, and expansion in two sympatric species that share relatively parallel demographic histories driven by historical human exploitation and bounties, followed by conservation and ongoing protection.

Intellectual merit: This research represents an empirical assessment of evolutionary theories relating to the genetic effects of demographic shift, including decline, recovery and geographic expansion. A comparison of genetic diversity among contemporary and archaeological samples (~500 years old) revealed a lasting signature of genetic bottleneck and the possible loss of a local, genetically distinct sub-population of gray seals in the Northeast US. To further investigate the subsequent period of population recovery, a genomic analysis of over 6,000 polymorphic gray seal loci and 2,700 polymorphic harbor seal loci was used to assess changes over time (the past 50 years) and space (Canadian Maritimes through Northeast US) in both neutral and adaptive regions of the genome.  This analysis identified spatial and temporal outliers that have changed more than expected during the recent recovery period, perhaps as a result of allele surfing and/or directional selection for traits that are favored during times of population growth or favored in new environments at the edge of the range expansion. This research is particularly relevant within the context of ongoing climate change that is likely to accelerate changes in population abundance and distribution in the future.

Broader impacts: The completed project provided training and mentoring to 1 female postdoctoral research fellow, 4 female undergraduate students, and 3 female high school students. There was a particular focus on training in analytical, bioinformatic, and laboratory skills that aimed to advance the development of the postdoctoral fellow’s career and research agenda in ecological and evolutionary genomics. In part as a result of this training fellowship, the postdoctoral fellow was offered and recently began a tenure-track faculty position in the School of Marine Sciences at the University of Maine.  Within six months of project completion, project results will have been disseminated at several invited university seminars (5), international conferences (3), and local outreach events (2), as well as through the publication of several manuscripts in scientific journals (4 published or pending).  Furthermore, to broadly contribute to the growth of ecological and evolutionary genomics in marine mammal science and encourage participation of other young scientists in the field, Dr. Cammen co-organized an international workshop on the topic during her fellowship and led the publication of a resulting open-source review paper.

Finally, the findings from this project will contribute to applied conservation measures and management of pinnipeds in the Northeast US. The results of the genetic analysis performed here provide insights into the historical ecology of the region, and suggest that the size of pre-exploitation pinniped populations were of the same magnitude as post-recovery pinniped populations. This finding has implications for how we view present-day abundance and recovery targets, in a system that lacks accurate baselines.  These results have been presented to the Marine Mammal Commission and NOAA Fisheries for consideration in future marine mammal policy development.
